awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Intracellular Patterning in the Ciliate Cell Cortex
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to identify universal mechanisms that organize specialized structures on the cell surface using the single-celled protozoan Tetrahymena thermophila.  Structures studied include ones important for both feeding and excretion.  Knowledge will be generated as to how newly synthesized cell-surface components are delivered to the proper location and in the proper abundance.  This project will engage early career scientists (primarily undergraduates) in genetics, cell biology, and advanced microscopy through a combination of independent and course-based research experiences.  This effort pilots a program to recruit students from under-represented backgrounds into mentored, collaborative research teams with long-term committed apprenticeships.  Along the way, we will develop the “Visible Cell”, a comprehensive teaching and research resource consisting of fluorescent cellular probes expressed in engineered cell-lines and made available to the broader research community.  This collection will include cells that express fluorescently-tagged proteins spotlighting specific organelles, membrane systems, and cytoskeletal components which can be studied in both the laboratory and the classroom. 

This research focuses on the Broadened Cortical Domain (BCD)1 gene, which when disabled, results in the assembly of multiple mouths and supernumerary excretory pores.  Sequence analysis of this gene reveals that its product resembles a protein involved in membrane trafficking.  Experiments are designed to test the hypothesis that the Bcd1 protein promotes endocytosis (retrieval of excess surface materials) through localized kinase activation.  These experiments include pharmacological and genetic manipulation of membrane trafficking and cell signaling pathways to elucidate how homeostasis of these pathways leads to proper assembly of cell surface organelles.  Finally, we will identify and characterize the gene that causes the janusA phenotype, a mirror-image duplication of the entire ventral organelle pattern.  Together, these studies of BCD1 and janusA will provide understanding of mechanisms that determine both the localization and dimensions of major cell surface structures and global cell patterning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The period covered by our recent NSF Grant entitled:  Collaborative Research: Intracellular Patterning in the Ciliate Cell Cortex, covers a remarkable period of unanticipated progress in the field of ciliate pattern research.  The organism that we study is a single cell, a ciliated protozoan.  As such, it seems at first glance, a simple form of life.  Upon closer examination, this single cell reveals a complexity of form that rivals the most sophisticated multicellular animal life, as it precisely orders a rich gallery of minute surface organelles along anterior-posterior, dorsal-ventral and even left-right axes of symmetry.  It recreates this rich pattern of structures with every cell division (See Figure 1).  In the 1980s and 1990s, my PhD advisor (Dr. Joseph Frankel) carried out a sophisticated program to identify mutants that affect this single-cell patterning.  He identified over 40 individual pattern mutants, but there was at the time, no method for discovering their corresponding genes.  In the past decade, we  began to identify these pattern genes through whole-genome-sequencing, something unimaginable during Joes career.  Several of my colleagues have identified 5 genes responsible for patterning along the anterior-posterior axis, with more gene-IDs being published every year.  What was remarkable, was that the very genes that create order within our one-celled model organism, were recognizable as the same genes crucially involved in patterning within metazoan, multicellular embryos.  This reflects the profoundly deep evolutionary roots of the mechanisms that create order in living tissues and cells.  With over 50 years of classical literature in the ciliate field, and the sudden emergence of a wealth of molecular data linking patterning processes from protozoans to the human form, there was an urgent need for a review of the literature.  I spent over a year working with Jacek Gaertig, to publish such a review (2022), giving the newest generation of advanced ciliate (and metazoan) pattern biologists a resource to help build perspective.  We exceeded the page limit of the journal two-fold, but the editors, recognizing its significance, allowed it.  I was also concerned that the study of ciliates (and Tetrahymena in particular) had grown remote from the non-specialist, so I published an article for the Encyclopedia of Life Sciences in 2022.  On the research front, and in collaboration with both Jacek Gaertig and Douglas Chalker, I set out to begin identifying Tetrahymena genes that control circumferential patterning (how a cell locates and assembles surface organelles around its circumference and controls their lateral dimensions).  Last fall we published a significant work identifying and characterizing the BCD1 gene from Tetrahymena, a gene that controls the dimensions of the cells organelles including its mouth and organs of excretion.  Of interest, this gene is homologous to genes in humans that have been linked to a variety of genetic disorders including autism and Chediak-Higashi syndrome.  Finally, I tackled the gene responsible for Frankels JanusA mutation, in which the Tetrahymena cell-pattern is duplicated creating a mirror-symmetric body plan (hence the name Janus).  We discovered that the gene responsible, is a polo-like-kinase, a gene found across both plant and animal kingdoms and hailed by some as the master control gene for mitosis and cell division.   We are currently investigating its role in controlling circumferential patterning in our simple cell.  I carried out this work in partnership with some talented collaborators, but also with the undergraduates in my lab.  During this period, I employed 16 undergraduates (averaging four per year), five of whom identified as students of color, and three who identify as neuro-divergent (ADHD or on the autism spectrum).  During the pandemic, I engineered our microscopy suite so that I could hold remote-online-real time microscopy sessions with both my research students and students enrolled in courses.  For this I was awarded the Cassling Innovation Award in 2020.   Many of my students are now enrolled in graduate programs successfully pursuing MD and PhD degrees.  Last summer, one of my undergraduates won the best undergraduate presentation at the Ciliate Molecular Biology conference held in Montpelier, France.  I look forward to continuing this fascinating work into the next decade.
